reasoning: First off, Microsoft isn’t in my circle of competence. I’ve spent my life sticking to simple businesses I understand – soft drinks at Coke, insurance with GEICO, retail with See’s – and I’ve steered clear of complex technology platforms. Second, while Microsoft shows strong operating margins, its ROE has averaged just over 7%, debt is relatively high at a 0.7 debt-to-equity ratio, and its earnings pattern is erratic. Those aren’t the hallmarks of a durable moat in my book. Third, management has issued new shares recently and pays minimal dividends. I like owner-oriented teams that plow capital into high-return projects or return it to shareholders, not dilute them. Fourth, financial consistency is lacking: inconsistent earnings growth and a low return on invested capital undercut any argument for a financial fortress. Fifth, valuation is way out of line. With a current market cap north of $225 billion and a negative 92% margin of safety against a $17,850 intrinsic value, you’re paying up for expectations that I don’t share. Sixth, I’m skeptical about long-term growth turning around enough to justify that premium—my DCF suggests negative growth in the near term before modest terminal gains. Finally, compared to the opportunities I already own – the dependable cash flows at Coca-Cola or the strong pricing power at See’s – Microsoft simply doesn’t offer the margin of safety or clarity I require. In plain terms, it’s a no for me.
